_children.body:
The oxidation states not shown by Mn in given reaction is :

$$ 3 \mathrm{MnO}_4^{2-}+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \longrightarrow 2 \mathrm{MnO}_4^{-}+\mathrm{MnO}_2+2 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O} $$

A. +6

B. +2

C. +4

D. +7

E. +3

Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below :
_children.explanation:
In the following reaction

$$3 \mathrm{MnO}_4^{2-}+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \longrightarrow 2 \mathrm{MnO}_4^{-}+\mathrm{MnO}_2+2 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$$

Oxidation state of Mn Species
+6 MnO$$_4^{2-}$$
+7 MnO$$_4^{-}$$
+4 MnO$$_2$$

So +2 and +3 oxidation state is not shown by Mn.

_children.body: The correct option for a redox couple is:

options.value: Both are oxidised forms involving same element.
Both are reduced forms involving same element.
Both the reduced and oxidised forms involve same element.

_children.explanation: Redox couple is both the reduced and oxidised form involve same element.

_children.body:
On balancing the given redox reaction,

$$\mathrm{aCr}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{7}^{2-}+\mathrm{bSO}_{3}^{2-}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{cH}^{+}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{aCr}^{3+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{bSO}_{4}^{2-}(\mathrm{aq})+\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\ell)$$

the coefficients $$\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}$$ and $$\mathrm{c}$$ are found to be, respectively -
_children.explanation:
Reaction has to be balanced in acidic medium 'O' atoms are balanced by adding $$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$$ and then $$\mathrm{H}$$-atom is balanced by adding $$\mathrm{H}^{+}$$ ions and charge is balanced by $$e^{\ominus}$$.

Oxidation: $$\left.\mathrm{SO}_{3}^{2-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-}+2 \mathrm{H}^{+}+2 e^{\ominus}\right] \times 3$$

Reduction: $$\mathrm{Cr}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{7}^{2-}+14 \mathrm{H}^{+}+6 e^{\ominus} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Cr}^{3+}+7 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$$

$$\mathrm{Cr}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{7}^{2-}+3 \mathrm{SO}_{3}^{2-}+8 \mathrm{H}^{\oplus} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Cr}^{3+}+3 \mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-}+4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$$

$$\mathrm{a}=1$$

$$\mathrm{b}=3$$

$$\mathrm{c}=8$$

_children.body: Which of the following reactions is a decomposition redox reaction?
_children.explanation:
Decomposition redox reaction leads to breakdown of a compound into two or more compounds at least one of which must be in the elemental state with change in oxidation number.

$$\mathrm{2Pb{\left( {N\mathop {{O_3}}\limits^{2 - } } \right)_2}(s) \to 2PbO(s) + 4N{O_2}(g) + \mathop {{O_2}}\limits^0 (g)}$$

_children.body:
For the redox reaction,
MnO4– + C2O4 2– + H+ $$ \to $$ Mn2+ + CO2 + H2O
The correct coefficients of the reactants for the balanced equation are

The correct order of N-compounds in its
decreasing order of oxidation states is
Hot concentrated sulphate acid is a moderately strong oxidizing agent. Which of the following reactions does not show oxidizing behaviour?
_children.explanation:
CaF2 + H2SO4 $$ \to $$ CaSO4 + 2HF

Here, the oxidation state of every atom remains the same so, it is not a redox reaction.

_children.body: The pair of compounds that can exist together is
_children.explanation:
Both FeCl<sub>2</sub>
 and SnCl<sub>2</sub>
 are reducing agents
with low oxidation numbers.

_children.body: A mixture of potassium chlorate, oxalic acid and sulphuric acid is heated. During the reaction which element undergoes maximum change in the oxidation number?
_children.explanation:
KClO3 + C2H2O4 + H2SO4 $$ \to $$ K2SO4 + CO2 + KCl + H2O

Maximum change in oxidation number of chlorine, i.e., from +5 to –1.

_children.body: Oxidation numbers of P in PO$$_4^{3 - }$$, of S in SO$$_4^{2 - }$$ and that of Cr in Cr<sub>2</sub>O$$_7^{2 - }$$ are respectively
_children.explanation:
Let oxidation number of P in PO4 3– be x.

$$ \therefore $$ x + 4(–2) = –3

$$ \Rightarrow $$ x = +5

Let oxidation number of S in SO4 2– be y.

$$ \therefore $$ y + 4(–2) = –2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ y = +6

Let oxidation number of Cr in Cr2O7 2– be z.

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 2z + 7(–2) = –2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ z = +6

_children.body: Number of moles of MnO$$_4^{ - }$$ required to oxidize one mole of ferrous oxalate completely in acidic medium will be
_children.explanation:
The balanced ionic equation for oxidation of ferrous oxalate by MnO4– in acidic medium is as follows :

3MnO4- + 5FeC2O4 + 24H+ $$ \to $$

3Mn2+ + 10CO2 + 12H2O + 5Fe3+

Thus, 5 moles of FeC2O4 require 3 moles of MnO4-.

So, 1 mole of FeC2O4 requires

= $${3 \over 5}$$ = 0.6 moles of MnO4-

_children.body:
Which is the best description of the behaviour of bromine in the reaction given below?
H2O + Br2 $$ \to $$ HOBr + HBr
_children.explanation:
H2O + $${\mathop {Br}\limits^0}$$2 $$ \to $$ HO$$\mathop {Br}\limits^{ + 1} $$ + H$$\mathop {Br}\limits^{ - 1} $$

In the above reaction the oxidation number of Br2 increases from zero (in Br2 ) to +1 (in HOBr) and decreases from zero (in Br2 ) to –1 (in HBr). Thus Br2 is oxidised as well as reduced and hence it is a redox reaction.

_children.body:
The oxidation states of sulphur in the anions

SO3$${_3^{2 - }}$$, S2O$${_4^{2 - }}$$ and S2O$${_6^{2 - }}$$ follow the order
_children.explanation:
SO32– : oxidation state of ‘S’ is +4

S2O42– : oxidation state of ‘S’ is +3.

S2O62– : oxidation state of ‘S’ is +5.

So, the order is S2O$${_4^{2 - }}$$ < SO$${_3^{2 - }}$$ < S2O$${_6^{2 - }}$$.
